title: Sentinel-1D reaches orbit on Ariane 6
summary: The Sentinel-1 mission – which provides radar vision for the Copernicus Earth observation programme – has a new addition to its family of satellites, with the arrival in orbit of Sentinel-1D, the last of the groundbreaking first generation. The launch took place at 22:02 CET (18:02 local time), on Tuesday, 4 November, on board an Ariane 6 launcher from Europe’s Spaceport in French Guiana.

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy November 2-8, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of November 2-8, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The Senate is in session this week. […]
detailed_news: This week marks the 25th anniversary of permanent occupancy of the International Space Station. The Senate is in session this week. The House continues to be in recess indefinitely except for pro forma sessions. NASA wants commercial companies to step forward with commercial space stations where NASA can be just one of many customers. At other events this week, representatives from those companies will be sharing their plans. It’s day 33 of the partial government shutdown. House Speaker Mike Johnson decided on Friday to keep the House out of legislative session for yet another week. The shutdown can only end if enough Senate Democrats/Independents decide to vote with most Republicans. There are quite a few interesting events here and overseas. There are lots of great meetings and conferences on tap this week. We highlight a few names that probably are familiar to the readers of this website. There does not appear to be a virtual option. Check back throughout the week for others we learn about later and add to our Calendar.

title: Live coverage: Commercial space station demo, data center precursor to launch on SpaceX Bandwagon mission
summary: SpaceX will fly 18 payloads to a mid-inclination orbit including an intelligence-gathering satellite for the military of South Korea. Liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is set for 1:09 a.m. EDT (0509 UTC).
detailed_news: Bandwagon-4, is the fourth multi-customer flight to a mid-inclination orbit and the 18th mission as part of SpaceX’s small sat ride share program. The mission will use Falcon 9 first stage booster B1091, which will eventually fly as a center booster for a Falcon Heavy rocket. The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a 95 percent chance for favorable weather at liftoff with just a small chance for interference from cumulus clouds. Starcloud believes that its future space-based data centers can be “ten times cheaper than land-based options” Philip Johnston predicted that “In 10 years, nearly all new data centers will be being built in outer space” Germany-based Exolaunch is responsible for manifesting and deploying 13 out of the 18 payloads flying.

title: Starship Block 3 and HLS: The Path to Get Back to the Moon
summary:
Amid numerous questions about whether SpaceX can have the Human Landing System (HLS) variant of…
The post Starship Block 3 and HLS: The Path to Get Back to the Moon appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX recently released an update regarding Starship and its Human Landing System variant. This variant of the Starship is set to be one of the landers for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s (NASA) Artemis program. The ship will operate alongside tankers and depots to refuel, enabling it to deliver not only people but also approximately 100 tons of cargo to the lunar surface. SpaceX has completed 49 milestones so far in the development of HLS. Docking adapter qualification has been achieved in conjunction with NASA and Lockheed. Landing leg testing, which included the dropping of a full-scale article at flight energies onto simulated lunar regolith, has also been completed. SpaceX currently has two test tanks at their Masseys test area. The first full flight test of Block 3 is scheduled to involve Booster 18 and Ship 39 and is expected to launch sometime in Quarter 1 of 2026. Currently, neither vehicle is complete in construction, and, based on the best timelines using past boosters and ships as reference points, neither will likely begin cryogenic proof testing until December. Ship 39 has a few noticeable changes, even though it is only a couple of sections into stacking. SpaceX has refined the design of the ship catch pins and relocated them to the nosecone. The common dome has moved down slightly, which means SpaceX will be able to load more LCH4 into the tank. Another significant addition is a probe-and-drogue docking system.

title: Thales Alenia Space Clears Key Milestone for In-Orbit Servicing Demo
summary:
A group of companies led by Thales Alenia Space has completed the System Preliminary Design Review for Italy’s In-Orbit Servicing (IOS) demonstration mission, funded through the government’s €191.5-billion National Recovery and Resilience Plan (PNRR). In May 2023, the Italian Space Agency (ASI) awarded a €235-million contract for the development of an in-orbit servicing demonstration mission […]
The post Thales Alenia Space Clears Key Milestone for In-Orbit Servicing Demo appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: A group of companies led by Thales Alenia Space has completed the System Preliminary Design Review for Italy’s In-Orbit Servicing (IOS) demonstration mission. The IOS mission will involve demonstrating a wide range of in-orbit servicing applications, including refuelling, component repair or replacement, orbital transfer, and atmospheric re-entry.

title: China Launches New Space Station Crew
summary: China launched a new three-person crew to their Tiangong-3 space station today. Shenzhou-21 lifted off at 11:44 am EDT and arrived at the space station about three hours later where […]
detailed_news: China launched a new three-person crew to their Tiangong-3 space station today. Accompanying the Shenzhou-21 crew are four mice, the first time rodents will be aboard a Chinese space station. Today is the 25th anniversary of the launch of the Russian-American crew that initiated permanent occupancy of the ISS. The ISS was mostly assembled over 12 years (1998-2010) and currently has a mass of about 420 Metric Tons. ISS is much larger than Tiangong-3, although China plans to expand it in coming years. title: Elon Musk on data centers in orbit: “SpaceX will be doing this”
summary: "We could see another transformation of what’s done in space."
detailed_news: Elon Musk says Starlink satellites could be used to build data centers in space. Musk’s interest in space-based data centers significantly raises the profile of the nascent industry. Proponents of the idea say the advantages are clear: free, limitless power from the Sun and none of the messy environmental costs of building these facilities on Earth. The first operational Starlink satellites launched a little more than half a decade ago with a mass of about 300 kg and a capacity of 15Gbps. Starlink V3 satellites will likely mass 1,500 kg. Ars Technica has been separating the signal from the noise for over 25 years.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 100th Starlink flight of 2025
summary: SpaceX has launched more than 2,500 of its satellites so far this year. It’s targeting liftoff of its Falcon 9 rocket from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base on Friday during a window that opens at 1:41 p.m. PDT (4:41 p.m. EDT / 2041 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing for a Halloween afternoon launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base. The company will use its oldest Falcon 9 booster that’s still in service to launch the Starlink 11-23 mission. The rocket will fly on a south-easterly trajectory upon departure from the California coastline. About 8.5 minutes after liftoff, B1063 will perform an autonomous landing on the drone ship 'Of Course I Still Love You'
